case_name: Not present in the provided text

facts.text: This appeal arises out of an application under article 226 of the Constitution made by the respondent-assessee for a writ quashing an order of assessment made under section 34 of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: It arises out of an application under article 226 of the Constitution made by the respondent-assessee for a writ quashing an order of assessment made under section 34 of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: The respondent made advance payment of tax under section 18A(1) of the Income-tax Act for the assessment year 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent made advance payment of tax under section 18A 1  of the Income-tax Act for the assessment year 1952-53.

facts.text: Regular assessment for the assessment year 1952-53 was made on August 30, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On August 30, 1952, regular assessment for this year was made and a part of the tax paid in advance was thereupon found refundable to the respondent.

facts.text: A part of the tax paid in advance was found refundable to the respondent after regular assessment.

anchor.surface_text: On August 30, 1952, regular assessment for this year was made and a part of the tax paid in advance was thereupon found refundable to the respondent.

facts.text: Rupees 14,720-14-0 interest was found payable to the respondent under section 18A(5) and paid some time in September, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Rupees 14,720-14-0 were found payable to the respondent under this provision and this sum was paid some time in September, 1952.

facts.text: Sub-section 5 of section 18A was amended on May 24, 1953 with effect from April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On May 24, 1953, sub-section  5  of the section 18A was amended with effect from April 1, 1952.

facts.text: Under the amendment to section 18A(5), the Government was to have paid Rs. 9,404-5-0 to the respondent instead of Rs. 14,720-14-0.

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to refer to this amendment in detail and it is enough to state that under it the Government was to have paid to the respondent Rs. 9,404-5-0 instead of Rs. 14,720-14-0.

facts.text: A notice was issued under section 34(1)(b) on March 18, 1957 stating that the Income-tax Officer had reason to believe that the respondent's income for the assessment year ending March 31, 1953 had been under-assessed and subject to excessive relief.

anchor.surface_text: On March 18, 1957, a numberice was issued under section 34 1  b  stating that as the Income-tax Officer had reason to believe that the respondents income for the assessment year ending March 31, 1953, had been under-assessed and had been the subject of excessive relief, he proposed to reassess the said income.

facts.text: The respondent protested the notice under section 34(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent protested, but proposed to reassess the said income. The respondent protested but, numberwithstanding the protest,

facts.text: Assessment under section 34 was made on July 30, 1957 notwithstanding the respondent's protest.

anchor.surface_text: numberwithstanding the protest, the assessment under section 34 was made on July 30, 1957.

facts.text: The order of reassessment on July 30, 1957 stated that as per amended section 18A(5), the assessee was entitled to less interest, excessive relief allowed under section 23(3), and action under section 34 taken to recover excess interest.

anchor.surface_text: The order of reassessment stated As per the amended provision of section 18A 5  the assessee was entitled to interest of a much smaller amount than what has been allowed to him during the original assessment. As excessive relief has been allowed to the assessee in the original assessment under section 23 3  and in order to enable me to recover the excess interest allowed action under section 34 was taken Hence I will proceed to recover the excess interest allowed to the assessee during the original assessment.

facts.text: The High Court of Bombay set aside the reassessment order on the respondent's application under article 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the respondent under article 226 of the Constitution this order was set aside by the High Court of Bombay. Hence this appeal.

facts.text: The appeal to the Supreme Court is from the High Court of Bombay's decision.

anchor.surface_text: SARKAR J. - This appeal is entirely without substance. It arises out of an application under article 226 of the Constitution made by the respondent-assessee for a writ quashing an order of assessment made under section 34 of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Counsel for the appellants relied only on two grounds from the notice: income under-assessed or excessive relief.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice under section 34 stated all these grounds but only two of them have been mentioned in the numberice which has been earlier set out by us become companynsel for the appellants has number relied on any other ground.

facts.text: The reassessment order of July 30, 1957 was based only on the ground that excessive relief had been allowed.

anchor.surface_text: It may be numbericed here that the order of July 30, 1957, was based only on the ground that excessive relief had been allowed. It did number hold that the income had been under-assessed.

facts.text: Learned counsel for the State sought leave at the hearing to contend that the order could be supported under section 35, but leave was refused as the point was not raised below and action was under section 34.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing learned companynsel for the State sought leave to companytended that the order of July 30, 1957, companyld be supported under section 35 of the Income tax Act. This leave was refused for such a point was number raised in the companyrt below and the action by the revenue authorities had expressly been taken under section 34 of the Act.

facts.text: Interest under section 18A(5) was payable on the amount paid in advance by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Under the provisions of sub-section  5  of section 18A, as it then stood, interest at a certain rate was payable on the amount paid in advance by an assessee under this section.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing learned counsel for the State sought leave to contend that the order of July 30, 1957, could be supported under section 35 of the Income tax Act.

issues.text: Whether any of the conditions under section 34(1)(b) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, namely that income has escaped assessment, been under-assessed, assessed at too low a rate, subject to excessive relief, or excessive loss/depreciation computed, were fulfilled to justify reopening the assessment?

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 of the Act under which the impugned order was made so far as material for our purposes is in these terms 34.  1  If -  b  the Income-tax Officer has reason to believe that income, profits or gains chargeable to income-tax have escaped assessment

issues.text: Whether the excess interest paid to the assessee under section 18A(5) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, prior to its retrospective amendment constituted under-assessment of income or grant of excessive relief under section 34(1)(b)?

anchor.surface_text: Under this section, therefore, an assessment earlier made can be reopened if income, profits or gains have escaped assessment or have been under-assessed or assessed at too low a rate, or have been made the subject of excessive relief, or excessive loss or depreciation has been computed. It does not seem to us that any of these conditions can be said to have been fulfilled in the present case.

issues.text: Whether the form of the notice of demand treats interest payable under section 18A(5) as part of the tax such that excess interest payment amounts to excessive relief?

anchor.surface_text: We were referred to the form of the notice of demand for the tax. It was contended that the form showed that in computing the tax interest under section 18A had to be taken into account. Therefore, it was said interest was a part of the tax and when more interest had been paid to the assessee then was due, it had been given excessive relief.

issues.text: Whether sub-sections (8) and (11) of section 18A of the Income-tax Act, 1922, indicate that interest under section 18A(5) payable by the Government is part of the tax or excessive relief?

anchor.surface_text: We were then referred to sub-section  8  and  11  of section 18A. Sub-section  8  provides for payment of certain interest by an assessee and sub-section  11  says that any sum other than a penalty or interest paid by an assessee under the provisions of section 18A shall be treated as a payment of tax.

issues.text: Whether the impugned reassessment order could be supported under section 35 of the Income-tax Act, 1922?

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing learned counsel for the State sought leave to contend that the order of July 30, 1957, could be supported under section 35 of the Income tax Act.

arguments.claim: Form of notice of demand shows interest under s18A taken into account in computing tax, so interest is part of tax and excess interest payment is excessive relief

anchor.surface_text: We were referred to the form of the notice of demand for the tax. It was contended that the form showed that in computing the tax interest under section 18A had to be taken into account. Therefore, it was said interest was a part of the tax and when more interest had been paid to the assessee then was due, it had been given excessive relief.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nyputed, the new law was number in fact there and, therefore, the companyputation had been according to the law then in force. That companyputation ca

arguments.court_reasoning: Wrong reading; form deducts interest to arrive at demand, interest not part of tax

arguments.claim: Provisions of ss18A(8) and (11) show that interest under s18A(5) is part of tax, so excess allowance is excessive relief

anchor.surface_text: We were then referred to sub-section  8  and  11  of section 18A. Sub-section  8  provides for payment of certain interest by an assessee and sub-section  11  says that any sum other than a penalty or interest paid by an assessee under the provisions of section 18A shall be treated as a payment of tax. It was contended that the provisions of these two sub-section show that the interest with which we are concerned is a part of the tax

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hat in companyputing the tax interest under section 18A had to be taken into account. Therefore, it was said interest was a part of the tax and when m

arguments.court_reasoning: Fallacious; subsections deal with interest payable by assessee, not by government

arguments.claim: Precedent in M. Chockalingam v. CIT shows penal interest is part of tax, analogizing that interest here is part of tax

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, our attention was drawn to civil Appeals Nos. 37-40 of 1962  M. Chockalingam v. Commissioner of Income-tax  in which referring to the proviso to section 35 of the Income-tax Act this court observed The learned counsel for the department raised the forlorn argument that the addition of penal interest is not enhancement of assessment as stated in the proviso. ... It was contended that this showed that the penal interest was part of the tax.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d sub-section  11  says that any sum other than a penalty or interest paid by an assessee under the provisions of section 18A shall be treated as a pa

arguments.court_reasoning: Different; penal interest paid by assessee, not interest paid by government to assessee

arguments.claim: Reassessment order can be supported under section 35

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing learned counsel for the State sought leave to contend that the order of July 30, 1957, could be supported under section 35 of the Income tax Act. This leave was refused for such a point was not raised in the court below and the action by the revenue authorities had expressly been taken under section 34 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d sub-section  11  says that any sum other than a penalty or interest paid by an assessee under the provisions of section 18A shall be treated as a pa

arguments.court_reasoning: Point not raised below; action expressly under s34

arguments.claim: Form of notice deducts interest, so not part of tax

anchor.surface_text: As was rightly pointed out by Mr. Kolah appearing for the respondent, this is a wrong reading of the form. The form specified the net amount of the tax payable and thereafter provided for deduction of certain interest to show the amount of the demand.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nyputed, the new law was number in fact there and, therefore, the companyputation had been according to the law then in force. That companyputation ca

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agrees it is wrong reading

arguments.claim: None of the conditions under s34(1)(b) fulfilled: no escapement, under-assessment, low rate, excessive relief, or excessive loss/depreciation

anchor.surface_text: Under this section, therefore, an assessment earlier made can be reopened if income, profits or gains have escaped assessment or have been under-assessed or assessed at too low a rate, or have been made the subject of excessive relief, or excessive loss or depreciation has been computed. It does not seem to us that any of these conditions can be said to have been fulfilled in the present case.

arguments.claim: Excess interest payment not under-assessment or excessive relief; provisional over-assessment of advance tax, interest computed per law in force, retrospective amendment does not trigger s34

anchor.surface_text: It does not seem to us that it is a case where the respondents income was under-assessed or where excessive relief was granted in computing that income. It is a case where tax had been paid in advance and upon subsequent regular assessment ... That computation cannot be reopened under section 34 because it cannot be said that it is a case either of under-assessment or of excessive relief having been granted. It is really a case where the statutory liability of the State to pay interest was reduced from a higher figure to a lower one.

holdings.text: None of the conditions specified in section 34(1)(b) of the Income-tax Act, 1922namely, that income has escaped assessment, been under-assessed, assessed at too low a rate, been subject to excessive relief, or excessive loss or depreciation has been computedwere fulfilled in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: It does not seem to us that any of these conditions can be said to have been fulfilled in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The excess interest payment resulted from a retrospective amendment reducing the government's statutory liability, not from any error in assessing or computing the assessee's income or relief under the law in force at the time of original assessment.

holdings.text: The excess interest paid to the assessee under section 18A(5) prior to its retrospective amendment does not constitute under-assessment of income or grant of excessive relief under section 34(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: It does not seem to us that it is a case where the respondents income was under-assessed or where excessive relief was granted in computing that income. It is a case where tax had been paid in advance and upon subsequent regular assessment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Original computation of interest was correct per law then in force; retrospective amendment affects government's liability to pay interest, not the assessee's income assessment or relief granted in computing income; provisional over-assessment of advance tax, not under-assessment.

holdings.text: Interest payable by the government under section 18A(5) is not part of the tax, as indicated by the form of the notice of demand which deducts such interest to arrive at the net demand.

anchor.surface_text: As was rightly pointed out by Mr. Kolah appearing for the respondent, this is a wrong reading of the form. The form specified the net amount of the tax payable and thereafter provided for deduction of certain interest

holdings.reasoning_summary: The form computes net tax payable and deducts interest payable to assessee, showing interest is not included in tax computation but a separate deduction for demand.

holdings.text: Sub-sections (8) and (11) of section 18A do not treat interest payable by the government under section 18A(5) as part of the tax or as excessive relief.

anchor.surface_text: These sub-section deal with interest payable by an assessee and we are concerned in this case with interest payable by the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The subsections expressly apply to interest and sums paid by the assessee to government, not vice versa; no application to government-paid interest.

holdings.text: The impugned reassessment order cannot be supported under section 35 of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing learned counsel for the State sought leave to contend that the order of July 30, 1957, could be supported under section 35 of the Income tax Act. This leave was refused for such a point was not raised

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point not raised in the court below and revenue action expressly taken under section 34, not section 35.

precedents.cited_holding: The learned counsel for the department raised the forlorn argument that the addition of penal interest is not enhancement of assessment as stated in the proviso. We do not see what else it could be.
